query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 «O Padre nostro, che ne’ cieli stai, 2 non circunscritto, ma per più amore 3 ch’ai primi effetti di là sù tu hai,
4 laudato sia ’l tuo nome e ’l tuo valore 5 da ogne creatura, com’ è degno 6 di render grazie al tuo dolce vapore.
query.result:
**English:**
1 "Our Father, who art in the heavens, 2 not circumscribed, but through greater love 3 than thou hast for thy first effects, thou hast,
4 praised be thy name and thy worth 5 by every creature, as is meet 6 to give thanks to thy sweet breath.
**Old English:**
1 "Ure Fæder ðe on heofonum eart, 2 ne eart ðu ymbscryd, ac ðurh mære lufe 3 ðe ðu hæfst to ðinum frumsceaftum, ðu hafast,
4 lofad sy ðin nama and ðin mærð 5 fram ælcre gesceaft, swa hit gewyrðe 6 ðancas to agyldenne ðinum swetan wætsman.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Vegna ver’ noi la pace del tuo regno, 8 ché noi ad essa non potem da noi, 9 s’ella non vien, con tutto nostro ingegno.
query.result:
**English:**
7 May the peace of your kingdom come to us, 8 because we cannot attain it by ourselves, 9 even with all our efforts, unless it comes to us.
**Old English:**
7 Cume ðin rice on usic, 8 forðam we hit ðurh us sylfe ne magon, 9 gif hit ðurh ðe ne cymð, mid ealle ure cræfte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Come del suo voler li angeli tuoi 11 fan sacrificio a te, cantando osanna, 12 così facciano li uomini de’ suoi.
query.result:
**English:**
10 As the angels of your will 11 make sacrifice to you, singing hosanna, 12 so may men do of theirs.
**Old English:**
10 Swa swa ðine englas ðines willan 11 ðe offriað lofsingende osanna, 12 swa ða men don ðara ðara.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Dà oggi a noi la cotidiana manna, 14 sanza la qual per questo aspro diserto 15 a retro va chi più di gir s’affanna.
query.result:
**English:**
13 From today on, the daily manna for us, 14 without which, in this harsh desert, 15 he who strives to go forward goes backward.
**Old English:**
13 Fram ðissum dæge ðe dæghwamlice mete, 14 butan ðam ðe ðurh ðas heardan westen 15 on bæc gæð se ðe furðor wyle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 E come noi lo mal ch’avem sofferto 17 perdoniamo a ciascuno, e tu perdona 18 benigno, e non guardar lo nostro merto.
query.result:
**English:**
16 And as we pardon each other the evil that we have suffered, 17 do thou also pardon us, and look not at our merit.
**Old English:**
16 And swa we ðæt yfel ðe we ðrowedon 17 forgifað ælcum men, and ðu forgif us, 18 milde heortan, ne beheald ðu ure geearnunga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Nostra virtù che di legger s’adona, 20 non spermentar con l’antico avversaro, 21 ma libera da lui che sì la sprona.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Our virtue, which is easily overcome, 20 do not test against the ancient adversary, 21 but free yourself from him who so spurs it on.
**Old English:**
19 Ure miht ðe ðurh lyt geswenced bið, 20 ne fandige ðu ðone ealdne andsaca, 21 ac alys ðe fram him ðe ðe swa spornð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Quest’ ultima preghiera, segnor caro, 23 già non si fa per noi, ché non bisogna, 24 ma per color che dietro a noi restaro».
query.result:
**English:**
22 This last prayer, dear lord, 23 is not made for us, for we have no need, 24 but for those who remain behind us.
**Old English:**
22 Þeos ytemeste bøn, leof hlaford, 23 nis nu for us selfum, forðæm we ne þurfon, 24 ac for ða ðe æfter us sculon lif lædan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Così a sé e noi buona ramogna 26 quell’ ombre orando, andavan sotto ’l pondo, 27 simile a quel che talvolta si sogna,
28 disparmente angosciate tutte a tondo 29 e lasse su per la prima cornice, 30 purgando la caligine del mondo.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Thus to themselves and us good speed 26 those shades were praying, and went beneath their burdens, 27 like those who sometimes dream,
28 variously distressed, all around 29 and weary on the first ledge, 30 purging the darkness of the world.
**Old English:**
25 Swa to himsylf and us godne gretunge 26 ða gesceaftas bædon biddende, and eodon under ðam byrðene, 27 gelice ðam ðe hwilum man mæg swefnian,
28 mislice gedrefede ealle ymbutan 29 and werige uppon ðam forman hrægle, 30 ða dimnesse ðisses middangeardes clænsende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Se di là sempre ben per noi si dice, 32 di qua che dire e far per lor si puote 33 da quei c’hanno al voler buona radice?
34 Ben si de’ loro atar lavar le note 35 che portar quinci, sì che, mondi e lievi, 36 possano uscire a le stellate ruote.
query.result:
**English:**
31 If good is always spoken of them in the afterlife, 32 what can be said and done for them here 33 by those whose will is rooted in goodness?
34 Their names should indeed be washed clean of the stains 35 that they carry from this world, so that, pure and light, 36 they may ascend to the starry spheres.
**Old English:**
31 Gif ðær æfre wel ymb ða wæs sægd, 32 hwat mæg ðonne her for ða gedon and gecweden 33 fram ðam ðe willað wel on ðam mode?
34 Hi ða sceolon ða naman wel awæscan 35 ðe hi ðanon heonon feriath, ðæt hi moton clæne and leoht 36 faran to ðam steorranhringum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 «Deh, se giustizia e pietà vi disgrievi 38 tosto, sì che possiate muover l’ala, 39 che secondo il disio vostro vi lievi,
40 mostrate da qual mano inver’ la scala 41 si va più corto; e se c’è più d’un varco, 42 quel ne ’nsegnate che men erto cala;
43 ché questi che vien meco, per lo ’ncarco 44 de la carne d’Adamo onde si veste, 45 al montar sù, contra sua voglia, è parco».
query.result:
**English:**
37 "Ah, may justice and pity move you soon, 38 so that you may move your wings, 39 and carry you aloft according to your desire,
40 show us from which side the shortest way 41 leads to the stairway; and if there is more than one passage, 42 teach us the one that descends less steeply;
43 for he who comes with me, because of the burden 44 of the flesh of Adam with which he is clothed, 45 is slow to climb, against his will."
**Old English:**
37 "Ea, gif rihtwisnes and mildheortnes eow hrade gedrefeð, 38 swa ðæt ge magon ða wægas hweorfan, 39 ðæt ge magon fleogan æfter eowrum willan,
40 tæcað us of hwylcere healfe ðæs stægeres 41 man mæg stigan on ðone sciortestan weg; and gif ðær is maran weg, 42 tæcað us ðone ðe læs steap is;
43 forðæm ðe ðes ðe mid me gæð, for ðære byrðene 44 ðæs flæsces Adames ðe he on wunað, 45 is slaw to ðam stigende, ongean his willan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 E s’io non fossi impedito dal sasso 53 che la cervice mia superba doma, 54 onde portar convienmi il viso basso,
55 cotesti, ch’ancor vive e non si noma, 56 guardere’ io, per veder s’i’ ’l conosco, 57 e per farlo pietoso a questa soma.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And if I were not hindered by the stone 53 that weighs down my proud neck, 54 so that I am forced to keep my face down,
55 I would look at that one who is still alive and does not name himself, 56 to see if I recognize him, 57 and to move him to pity for this burden.
**Old English:**
52 And gif ic ne wære gehefted mid ðam stane 53 ðe min ofermōde heafod geðwingð, 54 ðurh ðone ic sceal ðone hleor niðer habban,
55 ðone ðe gyt leofað and his noma næfð, 56 ic wolde ðone gesēon, ðurh ðæt ic hine gecneowe, 57 and ðurh ðæt ic hine milde makede ðisse byrðene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Io fui latino e nato d’un gran Tosco: 59 Guiglielmo Aldobrandesco fu mio padre; 60 non so se ’l nome suo già mai fu vosco.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I was Latin and born of a great Tuscan: 59 Guglielmo Aldobrandesco was my father; 60 I do not know if his name ever reached you.
**Old English:**
58 Ic wæs Læden and geboren of ðam miclan Tusce: 59 Guglielmo Aldobrandesco wæs min fæder; 60 ne wat ic gif his noma æfre wæs mid eow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 L’antico sangue e l’opere leggiadre 62 d’i miei maggior mi fer sì arrogante, 63 che, non pensando a la comune madre,
64 ogn’ uomo ebbi in despetto tanto avante, 65 ch’io ne mori’, come i Sanesi sanno, 66 e sallo in Campagnatico ogne fante.
query.result:
**English:**
61 The ancient blood and the noble deeds 62 of my ancestors made me so arrogant, 63 that, not thinking of our common mother,
64 I held every man in such great contempt, 65 that I killed him, as the people of Siena know, 66 and every child in Campagnatico knows it.
**Old English:**
61 Þæt ealde blod and þa æðelan dæda 62 minra yldrena me macodon swa ofermodne, 63 þæt ic ne hogode to þære gemænan moder,
64 ælcne man ic hæfde on swa miclum andsæte, 65 þæt ic hine ofsloh, swa þa Senisan wiston, 66 and hit wat on Campanicum ælc cniht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Io sono Omberto; e non pur a me danno 68 superbia fa, ché tutti miei consorti 69 ha ella tratti seco nel malanno.
query.result:
**English:**
67 I am Omberto; and not only to my own harm 68 does pride work, for it has dragged all my companions 69 with it into misfortune.
**Old English:**
67 Ic eom Omberto; and na ðurh me ane 68 ofermodigað, forðæm ðe ealle mine geferan 69 hæfð heo geteald mid hire on ðam teonan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E qui convien ch’io questo peso porti 71 per lei, tanto che a Dio si sodisfaccia, 72 poi ch’io nol fe’ tra ’ vivi, qui tra ’ morti».
query.result:
**English:**
70 And here it is necessary that I bear this burden 71 for her, until she has made amends to God, 72 since I did not do it among the living, here among the dead.
**Old English:**
70 And her ic sceal ðisne byrðen dreogan 71 for ðære, oð ðæt heo Gode genyhtsumie, 72 siððan ic hit ne mihte ða ic wæs on life, her on ðisse deaðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Ascoltando chinai in giù la faccia; 74 e un di lor, non questi che parlava, 75 si torse sotto il peso che li ’mpaccia,
76 e videmi e conobbemi e chiamava, 77 tenendo li occhi con fatica fisi 78 a me che tutto chin con loro andava.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Listening, I bowed my face; 74 and one of them, not the one who was speaking, 75 twisted under the weight that encumbers them,
76 and saw me and recognized me and called out, 77 keeping his eyes fixed on me with difficulty, 78 as I walked with them, completely bowed down.
**Old English:**
73 Hlystende ic abeah niðer minne neb; 74 and an ðara, nis ðes ðe ðær spræc, 75 awende hine under ðam byrðene ðe hyne bisgode,
76 and geseah me and oncneow and cleopode, 77 fæstende his eagan fæste on me 78 ðe ealra niðost mid him eode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 «Oh!», diss’ io lui, «non se’ tu Oderisi, 80 l’onor d’Agobbio e l’onor di quell’ arte 81 ch’alluminar chiamata è in Parisi?».
query.result:
**English:**
79 "Oh!" I said to him, "aren't you Oderisi, 80 the honor of Gubbio and the honor of that art 81 that is called illuminating in Paris?"
**Old English:**
79 "Eala," cwæð ic him, "ne eart ðu Oderisi, 80 Agobbio's wuldor and ðære cræfte wuldor 81 ðe man hæt in Paris 'enlumining?'"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 «Frate», diss’ elli, «più ridon le carte 83 che pennelleggia Franco Bolognese; 84 l’onore è tutto or suo, e mio in parte.
query.result:
**English:**
82 "Brother," he said, "the cards laugh more 83 than Franco Bolognese's paintbrush; 84 the honor is all his now, and mine in part.
**Old English:**
82 "Broðor," cwæð he, "ma þa cardas hlihið 83 ðonne Franco Bolognese's pensel; 84 se wuldor is eall his nu, and min sum dæl.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Ben non sare’ io stato sì cortese 86 mentre ch’io vissi, per lo gran disio 87 de l’eccellenza ove mio core intese.
query.result:
**English:**
85 I would not have been so courteous 86 while I was alive, because of the great desire 87 for the excellence to which my heart aspired.
**Old English:**
85 Ne wæs ic na swylce geþungen 86 ða ic lifgende wæs, for ðam miclan gefean 87 ðæs mægenþonces ðe min mod gesohte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Di tal superbia qui si paga il fio; 89 e ancor non sarei qui, se non fosse 90 che, possendo peccar, mi volsi a Dio.
query.result:
**English:**
88 For such pride here is the penalty paid; 89 and I would not be here now, if it were not 90 that, having the power to sin, I turned to God.
**Old English:**
88 For ðære modignesse her is ðæt feoh gylden; 89 and ic nære her gyt, nære ðæt, 90 ðæt ic, ða ic mihte synna fremman, me to Gode wende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Oh vana gloria de l’umane posse! 92 com’ poco verde in su la cima dura, 93 se non è giunta da l’etati grosse!
94 Credette Cimabue ne la pittura 95 tener lo campo, e ora ha Giotto il grido, 96 sì che la fama di colui è scura.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Oh, vain glory of human power! 92 How little green remains upon the top, 93 if it is not accompanied by the great ages!
94 Cimabue thought he held the field in painting, 95 and now Giotto has the acclaim, 96 so that the fame of the former is obscured.
**Old English:**
91 Ea, idle gylp ðara manna mægena! 92 Hu sliðe grene on ðære hean dun, 93 gif hit ne bið mid ðam miclum yldum!
94 Wende Cimabue on ðære scildgewritunge 95 ðæt he ðone feld geheolde, and nu hæfð Giotto ðone lof, 96 swa ðæt ðæs oderes lof is dim.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Così ha tolto l’uno a l’altro Guido 98 la gloria de la lingua; e forse è nato 99 chi l’uno e l’altro caccerà del nido.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Thus one Guido has taken from the other Guido 98 the glory of the language; and perhaps one is born 99 who will drive both of them from the nest.
**Old English:**
97 Swa hæfð ðone oðerne Guido 98 ðære spræce wuldor ofnumen; and mæg wæs geboren 99 se ðe hie begen of neste awearpeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Non è il mondan romore altro ch’un fiato 101 di vento, ch’or vien quinci e or vien quindi, 102 e muta nome perché muta lato.
query.result:
**English:**
100 The worldly clamor is nothing but a breath 101 of wind, which now comes from here and now from there, 102 and changes name because it changes direction.
**Old English:**
100 Nis ðæs weorold wyn buton gewites blæd, 101 windes swa ðæs þe hwilum hweorfað wide, 102 and his stefne styreð, and his strengðe læt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Che voce avrai tu più, se vecchia scindi 104 da te la carne, che se fossi morto 105 anzi che tu lasciassi il ‘pappo’ e ’l ‘dindi’,
106 pria che passin mill’ anni? ch’è più corto 107 spazio a l’etterno, ch’un muover di ciglia 108 al cerchio che più tardi in cielo è torto.
query.result:
**English:**
103 What voice will you have more, if you, old man, separate 104 the flesh from yourself, than if you had died 105 before you left behind the ‘pap’ and the ‘dindi’,
106 before a thousand years pass? For shorter 107 is the space to eternity than the movement of an eyelid 108 to the circle that is drawn latest in the sky.
**Old English:**
103 Hwilcne stefne hæfst ðu mare, gif ðu ða ealde 104 flæsc fram ðe selfum toslitst, ðonne ðu ær dead wære 105 ðonne ðu ða ‘pap’ and ða ‘dindi’ forlete,
106 ær ðonne ðusend wintra agangen wære? For ðam is læsse 107 fyrst to ðam ecan ðonne brymman beoð 108 to ðam hweole ðe siðast on heofonum bið geworht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Colui che del cammin sì poco piglia 110 dinanzi a me, Toscana sonò tutta; 111 e ora a pena in Siena sen pispiglia,
112 ond’ era sire quando fu distrutta 113 la rabbia fiorentina, che superba 114 fu a quel tempo sì com’ ora è putta.
query.result:
**English:**
109 He who takes so little of the road 110 before me, was once all Tuscany; 111 and now hardly a whisper of him is heard in Siena,
112 where he was lord when the rage of Florence, 113 which was so proud at that time, was destroyed, 114 just as now it is a whore.
**Old English:**
109 Se ðe ðæs weges lyt swigð 110 beforan me, wæs eall Toscane; 111 and nu on Senis næfre ne bismið,
112 ðær he wæs hlaford ða ða forwurðan 113 ða Florentiniscan yfelrædas, ða wæran 114 on ðam timan swilce nu syndon horan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 La vostra nominanza è color d’erba, 116 che viene e va, e quei la discolora 117 per cui ella esce de la terra acerba».
query.result:
**English:**
115 Your fame is like the color of grass, 116 which comes and goes, and he discolors it 117 through whom it emerges from the bitter earth.
**Old English:**
115 Eower hlisan is gelic cornes bleo, 116 ðe cymeð and gæð, and ðone awyðrað 117 se ðe hyne of ðære eorðan acerran læt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 E io a lui: «Tuo vero dir m’incora 119 bona umiltà, e gran tumor m’appiani; 120 ma chi è quei di cui tu parlavi ora?».
query.result:
**English:**
118 And I to him: "Your true humility encourages me, 119 and your great authority humbles me; 120 but who is he of whom you were just speaking?".
**Old English:**
118 Andichim:"Þinsoðfæstlæredmegleaweð, 119 andðinmicelweorðscipemegeeaðmeðað; 120 acðehwætisheðeðuærrihtnustæfnes?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 «Quelli è», rispuose, «Provenzan Salvani; 122 ed è qui perché fu presuntüoso 123 a recar Siena tutta a le sue mani.
query.result:
**English:**
121 "That one is," he replied, "Provenzan Salvani; 122 and he is here because he was presumptuous 123 in trying to reclaim all of Siena for himself."
**Old English:**
121 "Þæt is," he cwæð, "Provenzan Salvani; 122 and he is her forðæm ðe he wæs ofermodiȝ 123 on ðæm ðe he wolde Sienan ealle on his geweald habban."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Ito è così e va, sanza riposo, 125 poi che morì; cotal moneta rende 126 a sodisfar chi è di là troppo oso».
query.result:
**English:**
124 Thus it is and goes, without rest, 125 after he dies; such coin he pays 126 to satisfy the one who is too bold over there.
**Old English:**
124 Swa hit is and gæð, butan reste, 125 siððan he dead bið; swylce mede he geð 126 ðam ðe ðær oferhogode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 E io: «Se quello spirito ch’attende, 128 pria che si penta, l’orlo de la vita, 129 qua giù dimora e qua sù non ascende,
130 se buona orazïon lui non aita, 131 prima che passi tempo quanto visse, 132 come fu la venuta lui largita?».
query.result:
**English:**
127 And I: "If that spirit which awaits, 128 before it repents, the end of life, 129 dwells down here and does not ascend above,
130 if good prayers do not help it, 131 before as much time passes as it lived, 132 how was its coming here granted to it?".
**Old English:**
127 And ic: "Gif ðæt gast ðe ðær abid, 128 ær ðan ðe he onwæcne, ðæs lifes ende, 129 her niðer wunað and ne astihð ufor,
130 gif god gebed him ne helpð, 131 ær ðan ðe ðæs fæces fyrst gelimpe, 132 hu wæs his cyme hider geunnen?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Più non dirò, e scuro so che parlo; 140 ma poco tempo andrà, che ’ tuoi vicini 141 faranno sì che tu potrai chiosarlo.
query.result:
**English:**
139 I will say no more, and I know that I speak obscurely; 140 but a little while will pass, and your neighbors 141 will make it so that you will be able to interpret it.
**Old English:**
139 Ic ne secge na mare, and ic wat ðæt ic sprecu ðunne; 140 ac lyt ðære tide bið, ðæt ðine neahgeburas 141 doð swa ðæt ðu miht ðæt gereccan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Quest’ opera li tolse quei confini».
query.result:
**English:**
142 This work took those boundaries away from them.
**Old English:**
142 Þeos weorc him ða gemæro binam.
